comments.commentBody:
I have been very lucky lately to be a rather slow cyclist to be able to stop before motorists running red lights and j-walking pedestrians or joggers that just come out of nowhere in the middle of a street. In SF drivers are typically pretty aware of the bicycles around them but doesn't mean they are always respected, even as a pedestrian sometimes can be pretty dangerous.
somehow it feels like the end of year and around tax season, is always very stressful for drivers, and urban people on bikes or off bikes as pedestrians to concentrate and pay attentions. A few seconds of distraction from either end could cause a fatality. How many drivers as well as riders I see texting or on the phone - dont ask me it's depressing.
doesnt stop me from riding though, I feel better on a bicycle than in any motorized vehicle.
cheers -meli

Considering that both Tatis and Jacobs have been in the majors long enough for their potential to be known, and that their best days are past, there seems very little reason not to give Daniel Murphy 150+ games at first base, just to see what he can do. I find it encouraging that Jerry Manuel is inclining toward younger players, rather than buying into Omar Minaya's Grand Old Men of Baseball strategy.
Was Nate traded or what?

Bakes:

I wrote about the Knicks situation in detail in this blog yesterday, so I didn't repeat everything today. Here's yesterday's article: http://nyti.ms/b9NNgi

But to summarize, the Robinson trade had no net effect on their cap this summer, as long as Bill Walker is waived by July 7.

Larry Coon

Bakes, I read the rules of the game, too. Under Indirect free kicks, one of the four scenarios involving the goalie is the pertinent one:

• touches the ball with his hands after it has been deliberately kicked to him
by a team-mate

My reading of that is that the touch by Faibanski's foot, which was intentional, nullifies the infraction. I have seen goalies take a back pass, pop it up with their instep, and catch the ball. And haven't you seen a goalie receive a back-pass, dribble once or twice, and then pick it up? How is the intentional touch with the foot different than a single dribble. I think that Hansson was unreasonably swayed both by the Porto player jumping up and down with his hands in the air AND by Campbell's guilty reaction. Have you ever seen a referee demand the ball from a player, and then hand it to an opponent? I haven't, and I've been a serious fan for over 30 years. None of which excuses or forgives Arsenal's performance, particularly in the second half, when they showed themselves to be entirely bereft of attacking ideas.

Larry, a quick question if I could... What would Lebron's max salary number be (for cap purposes) if he were to sign with a team other than Cleveland? Assuming the low cap projections, would it be 105% of this season's salary (15.8 mil), or 105% of his option year salary (17.2 mil).

Also, would his cap number be his salary for his first year with the new team, or would it be the average of his yearly salaries over the life of the contract?

Your Salary Cap FAQ is fantastic, and great thanks to you for helping to illuminate this tricky CBA stuff !

Bottom line if Plushenko could have executed the rest of his jumps 100% and not had the majority in the first half he would have taken home gold....if you can't execute your program at 100% then you should think about downsizing it.....if a snowboarder performs a difficult trick but is sloppy on his basics should he win gold...one move does not make a program............poor sport

Mocha,  it really is not a numbers game.  The Scandinavian countries are far superior in the Nordic events.  The US usually has the largest team - but in 1988 we won only 6 medals.  20 years earlier. at Grenoble, the US won 1 medal, a Gold (Peggy Fleming.)  China, Russia, Canada and Germany also have nearly as large teams as the USA.   The USOC began the process 19 years ago, and American athletes are reaping the benefits.

Congratulations to Evan Lysacek and Frank Carroll! What a nice comeback from Torino. Too bad there couldn't be a fourth medal for Johnny Weir; he was amazing artistically though I'm happy for Daisuke Takahashi. Good for him for being so grateful and gracious.

Evan's program was the cleaner of the two.  Lysacek is definitely a complete skater.  Of course, the best, most expressive skaters of all time, Kurt Browning and Michelle Kwan, each the perfect combination of athlete and artist, never won an Olympic gold...

The Olympics is a reflection of our culture at any given moment. Excluding women from ski jumping, not having hardly any country (save Australia and New Zealand) from the southern hemisphere represented in Vancouver, building an extremely fast luge only to have it become the cause of an athlete's death, all suggest that, despite the tendency for us to revel in collaboration and cross-border friendships, we still have a ways to go as a planet.

All of this silly arguing over something that can only be subjectively judged.  Objectively, the Russian clearly did more.  The USOC should encourage Lysacek to give back the medal.  The IOC should really just end the madness by removing figure skating from the Olympic program.  Such an embarrassment.

Terrible, and heroic effort by the Slovenian skier.

Here's another scandal. The British female skeleton winner had aero ridges on her helmet. Anyone who watches motorsports, particularly F1 knows that those little ridges create a little turbulence that reduces drag over the helmet, an incredibly aero sensitive region seeing as the slider goes down head first.

There's no doubt in my mind that those ridges gave the British winner the aero edge that led to her huge margin of victory. Shocking, that they'd cheat in so obvious a way. The other teams are bound to file a protest. She even admitted on NBC that they were added after her last World Cup race and were not integral to the helmet, though according to the reporter the helmet was passed thru inspection and the ridges are "integral". How could they be both added recently, and "integral"?

http://www.nbcolympics.com...

Check out photos 6 and 7. The ridges are so obviously aero.

I will be shocked if the British press don't rip her to shreds, since most journos over there follow F1, and have an understanding of aerodynamics, not to mention the German journos.

RIdiculously blatant cheating.

"said Plushenko, adding that triple jumps were too elementary for men’s skating and the sport needed to move forward with harder elements."

Then why didn't he try for level 4 footworks and spins? Plushenko skated totally subpar yesterday with all those wonky landings and should be grateful he got such a high PCS.

Hey Chris in Seattle, I've been watching the Perilympics [the headline on the front page of the NY Times Feb. 11 special section on the Games, BEFORE anyone was killed] and it seems that a LOT of the most skilled athletes in the world fall down and go boom during their races and in training. Do you think maybe the people who design the courses should anticipate that, and not create a course which has a ravine two feet from the edge of the course right after a sharp turn?

Yes, in either the States or Canada, were Ms. Madjic to sue, she would find the doctrine of assumption of the risk -- or "no duty of care" -- a significant obstacle to winning the negligence lawsuit. However, many courts rule that the organizers of or participants in a sporting event DO have a duty to not cause harm to participants through their recklessness or gross negligence. Having seen the complete lack of any barriers by the side of the course where the ravine lurked so closely, I suspect Ms. Madjic would have a decent chance of convincing a court that the course creators were grossly negligent. Nevertheless, she still probably has the large problem that her damages won't be large enough to make it worth a lawyer's while to take the case and spend the considerable amount of time it will undoubtedly take to win it.
Besides, running four races in a few hours, against the best skiers in the world, and coming away with a bronze, all the while operating with four cracked ribs and a collapsed lung, has made Ms. Madjic an international hero. She never would have achieved such iconic status merely by winning a gold medal. So, the organizers can argue their negligence actually left her in a BETTER position than she would have been in had they been reasonably careful.

Hey, at least Olympic figure skating never fails to produce drama for the audience before, during, and after! Lol, nice illustrations:

http://chrisillustration.blogspot.com/

This has been in the news since at least Torino, probably long before. Couldn't they have announced in, say, 2000 that they would add women's ski jumping in 2010, giving people 10 yrs to train to get to that level?

Even if they're right that there aren't a lot of female ski jumpers, I think it's entirely wrong in 2010 to have a sport that both men and women do not compete in. Honestly, as long as you have, say, 10 world-class athletes, how many more do you need? You are only going to have 3 medalists anyway.
I ate her when I was Vieques last spring and it was absolutely fabulous, definitely our best meal while we were ther.  The sweet potato gnocchi was wonderful.

1A was mercifully gettable for a Saturday, and that gave me confidence. Puzzle fell in quadrants, NE, then SW, followed by SE, and finally NW. My top ten finish from yesterday should have an asterisk by it, since it seems most of the top solvers were too busy traveling to Brooklyn to bother doing the puzzle. Guess I better get some sleep if I'm going to make the 9:30 a.m. registration!

Beautiful Entries: crossing central entries, bien sur, plus PART-TIME, ONE-ARMED* (two of my favorite tasteless trivia questions: "How many arms are there in Def Leppard?" [9] and "How many testicles were in the starting lineup of the 1994 Philadelphia Phillies?" [17]), SOLAR CELLS, ROAD TO RUIN, GRAZIOSO, MARMOT, EPILOGUE, NEEDLING, IN-STATE

Clever Clues: "Like many student jobs," "Note from one who's shy," "Exposure warning?"* "Catchy thing?" "I.M. not sent through AOL?" (by far my personal favorite!), "Person making a check mark?"

Misdirection: thinking Citi Field not Madison Avenue for "Pitcher," topiary not hair styles for "bushes," thermodynamics not weaponry for "Heat," muscles not psyche for "soreness," human not guitar for "Neck," criminology not dermatology for "Breakouts," courthouse not schoolhouse for "class action," first name not last for "James" (WORTHY would've fit, but LEBRON is more relevant)

Errors: ENDORSER for ENDORSEE, IDEALISM for IDEALITY

New Words: Ran-tan, TIMBAL (was trying to make TIMPANUM fit), chthonic*, AGRObiology

New Facts About Old Words: Richard III quote, the Indian COBRA's genus and species (not quite as fun as Gorilla gorilla), MANILA's nickname

Wikipedia Worthy: KAZ(uo) MATSUI*, T(homas) S(tearns) Eliot (whose full name I had the pleasure of giving as a correct answer on JEOPARDY!), I(eoh) M(ing) Pei, STARA Zagora, USAIN BOLT* (was trying to make it a team once the first three letters turned out to be U.S.A.!), Cesare BORGIA, EMERIL Lagasse (from Fall River, MA, just like Lizzie Borden!), UNDERDOG, IRINA Spalko

Crosswordese: DAIL (2), one of the crossword puzzle's least favorite foreign legislatures, not as popular as the KNESSET (7) or DUMA (12) and appearing for the first time in 15 years, though I was shocked neither ALTHING nor STORTING has appeared during the Will Shortz era; ATE AT (been there, done that)

stayed at Filyos Residence on the golden horn...a newly renovated place that is a choice between a hotel and an apartment...definitely the best choice for longer stays...1 week, ten days or so...personnel unbelievably helpful, so clean and cozy flats inside...try this place if you plan to visit istanbul more than a week...

so silly, so sad, so ridiculous, really. full of the same macho regard that builds a luge track so it is fastest, most dangerous.

And then also moves the women farther down that track after they moved the men (reasonably so since it was too dangerous). god forbid women compete on equal ground - oh, we'll get there. thank you for highlighting this issue NYT.

there are a lot of problems at this Olympics where the Canadians and IOC failed to due adequate due dilegence, failed to THINK. there's this course, then the downhill where the athlete fell into a pit, then of course the luge. athletes come to TRUST The builders of these courses - yes they are dangerous sports - but this does not excuse suuuuuch short-sighted negligence. and what is worse is NBC is not holding anyone accountable, not doing the job of journalists.

OK, Evan Lysacek has a great career in politics if this skating thing doesn’t work out. Despite Plushenko poking sharp sticks at him all day long, he’s really held his cool and responded with graciousness and good humor. But man, plushenko needs to stop with the whole should have won because he did a quad thing.

It’s called ice skating, not ice jumping. It's the whole program, with many variables, not a single element. Read the rules. The scoring system didn't overly reward him for the thing he does very well-- jumping--and yet still held him accountable for the things he doesn't do as well. It was balanced, a whole package score. And his whole package score simply wasn't as good. The guy did an old school program, if he wants to place blame, he needs to look to his coach who apparently hasn’t been paying attention to how the sport has evolved.

While it’s a new scoring system, it’s not like it was new for Vancouver. It’s been in place for six years. Where have he and his coach been? He didn’t have any problem with the "new" scoring system when he won in 2006 or his competitions this year. With his continued comments, he's begining to embarass himself.

Todd. Did you even watch the skates all the way through? Because Plushenko's jumps weren't all clean and the second half of his program was lifeless. He should be happy with the silver. Lysacek deserved his win.

Americans wanted this medal and we got it. It was a Canadian payback for the undeserved gold medals of Salle/Pelletier. However, Evgeny Plushenko was robbed. Not only Russians are outraged, but the whole honest world. Unfortunately commentators like Marlene here do not read other languages. Well, America, lets enjoy our rotten gold medal.
